t: Luke 6
Lord of the Sabbath
On*p a Sabbath, he passed through the grainfields. His disciples were picking heads of grain, rubbing them in their hands, and eating them.
But some of the Pharisees said, “Why are you doing what is not lawful on the Sabbath?”
Jesus*p answered them, “Haven’t*r you*r read*r what*r David*r and*r those*r who*r were*r with*r him*r did*r when*r he*r was*r hungry —*r

how*r he*r entered*r the*r house*r of*r God*r and*r took*r and*r ate*r the*r bread*r of*r the*r Presence,*r which*r is*r not*r lawful*r for*r any*r but*r the*r priests*r to*r eat?*r He*r even*r gave*r some*r to*r those*r who*r were*r with*r him.”*r
Then he told them, “The*r Son*r of*r Man*r is*r Lord*r of*r the*r Sabbath.”*r
On*p another Sabbath he entered the synagogue and was teaching. A man was there whose right hand was shriveled.
The scribes and Pharisees were watching him closely, to see if he would heal on the Sabbath, so that they could find a charge against him.
But he knew their thoughts and told the man with the shriveled hand, “Get*r up*r and*r stand*r here.”*r So he got up and stood there.
Then Jesus said to them, “I*r ask*r you:*r Is*r it*r lawful*r to*r do*r good*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r or*r to*r do*r evil,*r to*r save*r life*r or*r to*r destroy*r it?”*r
After looking around at them all, he told him, “Stretch*r out*r your*r hand.”*r He did, and his hand was restored.
They, however, were filled with rage and started discussing with one another what they might do to Jesus.
The Twelve Apostles
During*p those days he went out to the mountain to pray and spent all night in prayer to God.
When daylight came, he summoned his disciples, and he chose twelve of them, whom he also named apostles:
Simon, whom he also named Peter, and Andrew his brother; James and John; Philip and Bartholomew;
Matthew and Thomas; James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon called the Zealot;
Judas the son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor.
Teaching and Healing
After*p coming down with them, he stood on a level place with a large crowd of his disciples and a great number of people from all Judea and Jerusalem and from the seacoast of Tyre and Sidon.
They came to hear him and to be healed of their diseases; and those tormented by unclean spirits were made well.
The whole crowd was trying to touch him, because power was coming out from him and healing them all.
The Beatitudes
Then*p looking up at his disciples, he said: Blessed*rpn are*r you*r who*r are*r poor,*r because*rln the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r yours.*r
Blessed*rln are*r you*r who*r are*r hungry*r now,*r because*rln you*r will*r be*r filled.*r Blessed*rln are*r you*r who*r weep*r now,*r because*rln you*r will*r laugh.*r
Blessed*rln are*r you*r when*r people*r hate*r you,*r when*rln they*r exclude*r you,*r insult*r you,*r and*rln slander*r your*r name*r as*r evil*r because*rln of*r the*r Son*r of*r Man.*r

“Rejoice*rp in*r that*r day*r and*r leap*r for*r joy.*r Take*r note — your*r reward*r is*r great*r in*r heaven,*r for*r this*r is*r the*r way*r their*r ancestors*r used*r to*r treat*r the*r prophets.*r
Woe to the Self-Satisfied
But*rpn woe*r to*r you*r who*r are*r rich,*r for*rln you*r have*r received*r your*r comfort.*r
Woe*rln to*r you*r who*r are*r now*r full,*r for*rln you*r will*r be*r hungry.*r Woe*rln to*r you*r who*r are*r now*r laughing,*r for*rln you*r will*r mourn*r and*r weep.*r
Woe*rln to*r you*r when*rln all*r people*r speak*r well*r of*r you,*r for*rln this*r is*r the*r way*r their*r ancestors*r used*rln to*r treat*r the*r false*r prophets.*r
Love Your Enemies
“But*rp I*r say*r to*r you*r who*r listen:*r Love*r your*r enemies,*r do*r what*r is*r good*r to*r those*r who*r hate*r you,*r
bless*r those*r who*r curse*r you,*r pray*r for*r those*r who*r mistreat*r you.*r
If*r anyone*r hits*r you*r on*r the*r cheek,*r offer*r the*r other*r also.*r And*r if*r anyone*r takes*r away*r your*r coat,*r don’t*r hold*r back*r your*r shirt*r either.*r
Give*r to*r everyone*r who*r asks*r you,*r and*r from*r someone*r who*r takes*r your*r things,*r don’t*r ask*r for*r them*r back.*r
Just*r as*r you*r want*r others*r to*r do*r for*r you,*r do*r the*r same*r for*r them.*r
If*r you*r love*r those*r who*r love*r you,*r what*r credit*r is*r that*r to*r you?*r Even*r sinners*r love*r those*r who*r love*r them.*r
If*r you*r do*r what*r is*r good*r to*r those*r who*r are*r good*r to*r you,*r what*r credit*r is*r that*r to*r you?*r Even*r sinners*r do*r that.*r
And*r if*r you*r lend*r to*r those*r from*r whom*r you*r expect*r to*r receive,*r what*r credit*r is*r that*r to*r you?*r Even*r sinners*r lend*r to*r sinners*r to*r be*r repaid*r in*r full.*r

But*r love*r your*r enemies,*r do*r what*r is*r good,*r and*r lend,*r expecting*r nothing*r in*r return.*r Then*r your*r reward*r will*r be*r great,*r and*r you*r will*r be*r children*r of*r the*r Most*r High.*r For*r he*r is*r gracious*r to*r the*r ungrateful*r and*r evil.*r
Be*r merciful,*r just*r as*r your*r Father*r also*r is*r merciful.*r
Do Not Judge
“Do*rp not*r judge,*r and*r you*r will*r not*r be*r judged.*r Do*r not*r condemn,*r and*r you*r will*r not*r be*r condemned.*r Forgive,*r and*r you*r will*r be*r forgiven.*r

Give,*r and*r it*r will*r be*r given*r to*r you;*r a*r good*r measure — pressed*r down,*r shaken*r together,*r and*r running*r over — will*r be*r poured*r into*r your*r lap.*r For*r with*r the*r measure*r you*r use,*r it*r will*r be*r measured*r back*r to*r you.”*r
He*p also told them a parable: “Can*r the*r blind*r guide*r the*r blind?*r Won’t*r they*r both*r fall*r into*r a*r pit?*r
A*r disciple*r is*r not*r above*r his*r teacher,*r but*r everyone*r who*r is*r fully*r trained*r will*r be*r like*r his*r teacher.*r
“Why*rp do*r you*r look*r at*r the*r splinter*r in*r your*r brother’s*r eye,*r but*r don’t*r notice*r the*r beam*r of*r wood*r in*r your*r own*r eye?*r

Or*r how*r can*r you*r say*r to*r your*r brother,*r ‘Brother,*r let*r me*r take*r out*r the*r splinter*r that*r is*r in*r your*r eye,’*r when*r you*r yourself*r don’t*r see*r the*r beam*r of*r wood*r in*r your*r eye?*r Hypocrite!*r First*r take*r the*r beam*r of*r wood*r out*r of*r your*r eye,*r and*r then*r you*r will*r see*r clearly*r to*r take*r out*r the*r splinter*r in*r your*r brother’s*r eye.*r
A Tree and Its Fruit
“A*rp good*r tree*r doesn’t*r produce*r bad*r fruit;*r on*r the*r other*r hand,*r a*r bad*r tree*r doesn’t*r produce*r good*r fruit.*r
For*r each*r tree*r is*r known*r by*r its*r own*r fruit.*r Figs*r aren’t*r gathered*r from*r thornbushes,*r or*r grapes*r picked*r from*r a*r bramble*r bush.*r

A*r good*r person*r produces*r good*r out*r of*r the*r good*r stored*r up*r in*r his*r heart.*r An*r evil*r person*r produces*r evil*r out*r of*r the*r evil*r stored*r up*r in*r his*r heart,*r for*r his*r mouth*r speaks*r from*r the*r overflow*r of*r the*r heart.*r
The Two Foundations
“Why*rp do*r you*r call*r me*r ‘Lord,*r Lord,’*r and*r don’t*r do*r the*r things*r I*r say?*r
I*r will*r show*r you*r what*r someone*r is*r like*r who*r comes*r to*r me,*r hears*r my*r words,*r and*r acts*r on*r them:*r

He*r is*r like*r a*r man*r building*r a*r house,*r who*r dug*r deep*r and*r laid*r the*r foundation*r on*r the*r rock.*r When*r the*r flood*r came,*r the*r river*r crashed*r against*r that*r house*r and*r couldn’t*r shake*r it,*r because*r it*r was*r well*r built.*r

But*r the*r one*r who*r hears*r and*r does*r not*r act*r is*r like*r a*r man*r who*r built*r a*r house*r on*r the*r ground*r without*r a*r foundation.*r The*r river*r crashed*r against*r it,*r and*r immediately*r it*r collapsed.*r And*r the*r destruction*r of*r that*r house*r was*r great.”*r
